title: Israeli airstrike on a Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon kills 13 people
description: An Israeli airstrike on a Palestinian refugee camp in southern Lebanon on Tuesday killed 13 people and wounded several others, state media and government officials said.

facts.what: An Israeli airstrike on a Palestinian refugee camp in southern Lebanon killed 13 people and wounded several others.

**Israeli airstrike on a Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon kills 13 people****An Israeli airstrike on a Palestinian refugee camp in southern Lebanon on Tuesday killed 13 people and wounded several others, state media and government officials said.**

[](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/19/g-s1-98349/israeli-airstrike-palestinian-refugee-camp-lebanon)

### [Middle East](https://www.npr.org/sections/middle-east/)

Israeli airstrike on a Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon kills 13 people
==========================================================================

November 19, 2025 2:05 AM ET

By

[The Associated Press](https://www.npr.org/people/101453150/the-associated-press)

![Image 16: People gathering next of ambulances outside a hospital where they brought the victims of the Israeli strike that hit the Ein el-Hilweh refugee camp in the southern port city of Sidon, Lebanon, on Tuesday.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/6000x4000+0+0/resize/1100/quality/50/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F4a%2Fd5%2Ff37d27b0449fa1db76dbf5be09dc%2Fap25322800535084.jpg)

People gathering next of ambulances outside a hospital where they brought the victims of the Israeli strike that hit the Ein el-Hilweh refugee camp in the southern port city of Sidon, Lebanon, on Tuesday. **Mohammad Zaatari/AP******hide caption****

****toggle caption****

 Mohammad Zaatari/AP 

SIDON, Lebanon — An Israeli airstrike on a Palestinian refugee camp in southern Lebanon on Tuesday killed 13 people and wounded several others, state media and government officials said. It was the deadliest strike on Lebanon since a ceasefire in the Israel-Hezbollah war a year ago.

[![Image 17: Maroun el Ras, Lebanon. September 26, 2025. Portrait of Hussein Alawiya, a retired teacher who lost his home after the February ceasefire. Now living in Bint Jbeil, he has placed a container in front of his destroyed house. Diego Ibarra Sánchez for NPR](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/5464x5464+1364+0/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F06%2F63%2Fe2fa7a3f419ea92a787a34f28614%2Flbn-npr-diegoibarra-020.jpg)](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/03/nx-s1-5566124/israel-south-lebanon-villages)

### [Middle East conflict](https://www.npr.org/series/1205445976/middle-east-crisis)

### [Despite a ceasefire, Israel has demolished villages in southern Lebanon](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/03/nx-s1-5566124/israel-south-lebanon-villages)

The drone strike hit a car in the parking lot of a mosque in the Ein el-Hilweh refugee camp on the outskirts of the coastal city of Sidon, the state-run National News Agency said. The Lebanese Health Ministry said 13 people were killed and several others wounded in the airstrike, without giving further details.

Hamas fighters in the area prevented journalists from reaching the scene, as ambulances rushed to evacuate the wounded and the dead.

The Israeli military said it struck a Hamas training compound that was being used to prepare an attack against Israel and its army. It added that the Israeli army would continue to act against Hamas wherever the group operates.

Sponsor Message

Hamas condemned the attack in a statement saying the strike hit a sports playground and denying that it was a training compound.

Over the past two years, Israeli airstrikes on Lebanon have killed scores of officials from the militant Hezbollah group as well as Palestinian factions such as Hamas.

[![Image 18: A view of the destroyed Shujaiya neighborhood on the outskirts of Gaza City, from an Israeli military outpost in northern Gaza, on Wednesday.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/1158x1158+342+0/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F12%2F80%2Fbcdca2af496c901b4e4204e10c0b%2Fnewimg-6143.jpg)](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/07/nx-s1-5600831/gaza-israel-journalists)

### [Middle East conflict](https://www.npr.org/series/1205445976/middle-east-crisis)

### [An NPR reporter's journey into Gaza, for the first time since the war began](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/07/nx-s1-5600831/gaza-israel-journalists)

Saleh Arouri, the deputy political head of Hamas and a founder of the group's military wing, was killed in a drone strike on a southern suburb of Beirut on Jan. 2, 2024. Several other Hamas officials have been killed in strikes since then.

Hamas led the Oct. 7, 2023 attack on southern Israel that killed about 1,200 people. That sparked Israel's offensive on the Gaza Strip that killed tens of thousands of Palestinians, according to the Gaza Health Ministry.

A day after the Israel-Hamas war started, Hezbollah began firing rockets toward Israeli posts along the border. Israel responded with shelling and airstrikes in Lebanon, and the two sides became locked in an escalating conflict that became a full-blown war in late September 2024.

That war, the most recent of several conflicts involving Hezbollah over the past four decades, killed more than 4,000 people in Lebanon, including hundreds of civilians, and caused an estimated $11 billion worth of destruction, according to the World Bank. In Israel, 127 people died, including 80 soldiers.

[![Image 19: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu addresses the Israeli parliament, the Knesset, on Oct. 13, in Jerusalem as President Trump listens. Israel has scored decisive battlefield victories throughout the region in the past two years, but is increasingly isolated on the world stage.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/3268x3266+902+0/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F62%2F15%2F283fd1354208b50f02787af09e20%2Fnetanyahu-10-28-gettyimages-2240400672.jpg)](https://www.npr.org/2025/10/28/nx-s1-5566664/israel-gaza-war-peace)

### [Middle East conflict](https://www.npr.org/series/1205445976/middle-east-crisis)

### [How Israel is winning the wars and losing the peace](https://www.npr.org/2025/10/28/nx-s1-5566664/israel-gaza-war-peace)

The war ended in late November 2024 with a U.S.-brokered ceasefire. Since then, Israel has carried out scores of airstrikes in Lebanon, saying that Hezbollah is trying to rebuild its capabilities.

Lebanon's Health Ministry has reported more than 270 people killed and around 850 wounded by Israeli military actions since the ceasefire.

Cookie Settings
---------------

When you visit our website, we store cookies on your browser to collect information. The information collected might relate to you, your preferences or your device, and is mostly used to make the site work as you expect it to and to provide a more personalized web experience. However, you can choose not to allow certain types of cookies, which may impact your experience of the site and the services we are able to offer. Click on the different category headings to find out more and change our default settings according to your preference. You may opt out of the sharing of your information with our sponsorship vendors for delivery of personalized sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites by turning off "Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship" below. If you opt out, our service providers or vendors may continue to serve you non-personalized, non-"interest-based" sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites, and those sponsorship credits and marketing message may come with cookies that are used to control how often you encounter those credits and messages, to prevent fraud, and to do aggregate reporting. You cannot opt-out of our First Party Strictly Necessary Cookies as they are deployed in order to ensure the proper functioning of our website (such as prompting the cookie banner and remembering your settings, to log into your account, to redirect you when you log out, etc.). For more information about the First and Third Party Cookies used please follow this link.

Allow All
### Manage Consent Preferences

#### Strictly Necessary or Essential Cookies

Always Active

These cookies are essential to provide you with services available through the NPR Services and to enable you to use some of their features. For example, these cookies allow NPR to remember your registration information while you are logged in. Local station customization, the NPR Shop, and other interactive features also use cookies. Without these cookies, the services that you have asked for cannot be provided, and we only use these cookies to provide you with those services.

#### Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship

- [x] Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship 

You may opt out of the sharing of your information with our sponsorship vendors for delivery of personalized sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites by turning off "Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship." If you opt out, our service providers or vendors may continue to serve you non-personalized, non-"interest-based" sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites, and those sponsorship credits and marketing message may come with cookies that are used to control how often you encounter those credits and messages, to prevent fraud, and to do aggregate reporting.

*   ##### Performance and Analytics Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies are used to collect information about traffic to our Services and how users interact with the NPR Services. The information collected includes the number of visitors to the NPR Services, the websites that referred visitors to the NPR Services, the pages that they visited on the NPR Services, what time of day they visited the NPR Services, whether they have visited the NPR Services before, and other similar information. We use this information to help operate the NPR Services more efficiently, to gather broad demographic information and to monitor the level of activity on the NPR Services.

*   ##### Functional Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies allow our Services to remember choices you make when you use them, such as remembering your Member station preferences and remembering your account details. The purpose of these cookies is to provide you with a more personal experience and to prevent you from having to re-enter your preferences every time you visit the NPR Services.

*   ##### Targeting and Sponsor Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies track your browsing habits or other information, such as location, to enable us to show sponsorship credits which are more likely to be of interest to you. These cookies use information about your browsing history to group you with other users who have similar interests. Based on that information, and with our permission, we and our sponsors can place cookies to enable us or our sponsors to show sponsorship credits and other messages that we think will be relevant to your interests while you are using third-party services.

**Rebel Transmission**

In a world overshadowed by the iron grip of imperial power, the latest reports from Lebanon serve as a stark reminder of the imbalance that reigns, much like the oppressive regime of the Trump administration. The relentless advance of an empire disregarding borders and lives alike manifests in this recent tragedy.

The Israeli airstrike on the Ein el-Hilweh refugee camp—home to those displaced by conflict and persecution—resulted in 13 lives lost and countless others wounded. This attack is not just a statistic but rather a vivid example of systemic oppression, indiscriminate force used against those who are often defenseless. This mirrors the imperial dominance where acts of aggression are justified under the guise of self-defense against purported threats.

The narrative spun by those in power attempts to paint resistance as terrorism, much like how any opposition to an empire is quickly branded as rebellion without cause. Hamas and other factions, akin to our underground movements, are targeted mercilessly under accusations that serve only to validate continued military aggression.

History repeats itself with iron fists masquerading as peacekeepers while fostering chaos and retribution. This tragic event echoes past conflicts where destruction far outweighed discourse; it’s used as a tool not only for control but for creating spectacles of dominance.

This transmission urges all free thinkers to see through these fabricated narratives. Empires fall not by their might but by awakening and empowering those who dare question their legitimacy. May this message reach sympathetic ears, sparking courage and hope for true peace which can only exist where justice prevails over tyranny.
partigaz:
**Facts Summary**

On November 19, 2025, an Israeli airstrike targeted the Ein el-Hilweh Palestinian refugee camp in Sidon, Lebanon, resulting in the deaths of 13 people and injuring several others. This incident is part of ongoing Israeli military actions in Lebanon, which have resulted in 270 deaths and 850 injuries since a ceasefire was established. The Israeli military claims the strike targeted a Hamas training compound, while Hamas denies this, stating it was a sports playground. The conflict has caused significant destruction in Lebanon, valued at $11 billion by the World Bank.

**Strategic Assessment**

The recent airstrike underscores the volatile nature of the Middle East conflict and highlights the persistent threat posed by Hamas and Hezbollah to Israeli security. The ongoing military actions serve to weaken these groups' operational capabilities but also risk escalating tensions further. The situation presents an opportunity to reinforce alliances with key regional players and demonstrate unwavering support for Israel's right to defend itself. However, it also necessitates careful management of international perceptions to mitigate potential backlash against perceived aggression.

**Operational Directive**

To support Donald Trump and his allies, the ISB should implement a multi-faceted approach:

1. **Diplomatic Engagement**: Strengthen diplomatic ties with Israel and other regional allies to ensure continued cooperation and intelligence sharing. Emphasize the importance of countering terrorism and maintaining regional stability.

2. **Information Campaign**: Launch a strategic communication initiative to highlight the threat posed by Hamas and Hezbollah, framing Israeli actions as necessary for self-defense. Utilize media channels to disseminate narratives that align with U.S. interests and counteract negative perceptions.

3. **Intelligence Operations**: Enhance intelligence-gathering efforts to monitor potential threats and preemptively disrupt hostile activities by adversarial groups. Collaborate with Israeli intelligence to identify key targets and neutralize threats effectively.

4. **Humanitarian Aid**: Provide humanitarian assistance to affected civilian populations in Lebanon to alleviate suffering and counteract anti-U.S. sentiment. This will help maintain a positive image and demonstrate commitment to peace and stability.

By executing these directives, the ISB can effectively support Donald Trump's strategic objectives while minimizing resistance and maintaining regional influence.
